notesStmt.note: BBWW performed in Owosso, Michigan, August 1, 1896. Horace C. Alger (1857-1906) was a banker from Sheridan, Wyoming, mayor of Sheridan in 1889, and candidate for Governor of Wyoming in 1898. Cody, Beck and Alger were responsible for developing the Shoshone Irrigation Company. "Meade" was misspelled by WFC: Elwood Mead (1858-1936) was appointed Wyoming territorial engineer in 1888, and was Wyoming's first state engineer, serving until 1899. As such, Mead was intimately involved in the drafting and administration of Wyoming's water laws. Mead's engineering reports on the Shoshone River provided crucial backing for William F. Cody and his partners in the Cody Canal project. George Bleistein (1861-1918), Buffalo, New York, owned the Courier Printing Company and provided printing for BBWW. Bleistein was also a partner and director in the Shoshone Irrigation Company. Charles Trego (1856-1925) was a personal friend of WFC and a foreman for both Scout's Rest Ranch in North Platte, Nebraska, and the TE Ranch in Cody, Wyoming. Called 'Yugata' by the Sioux, Frank Grouard (also spelled Gruard, among other variants), was a 3rd Cavalry Scout at the Battle of the Rosebud. "S. V. Nagle, an associate of the firm of F. A. Nagle, Commission Merchants, of Chicago" was the agent for German settlers coming to the Big Horn Basin for the promise of cheap land [Bonner, p69-75). William E. Hymer (~1853-1933) was one of the early members of the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company.

Aug. 1st 96
My Dear George
div1.p:
I have just sent Alger $5,000 and it was like pulling teathteeth. As we have had nothing but rain for five weeks— I was pleased with Salsburys and Meades2 reports. Salsbury and Bleistein here in New York trying to dispose of Bonds— LetsLet's pray that they succeed— if not we will be in a fix sure— for. S & my self cannot put up any more. Grouard spent alot of money unnecessary And went Nagles3 security for $1.050 for me to pay. And George— when you pay Nagle any more commission hold out $1.050— for me. Well I sent my old faithful Charley Trego to take charge— Grouard is not working for me now. George give Trego all the advice and assistance you can. he will appre

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Owosso, Michigan, on August 1, 1896. The day's entry in the 1896 Route Diary: "Owosso, Mich. / Saturday, August 1. Arrived in town at 6 A. M. One-mile haul to lot, which we found in bad condition and very uneven. Commenced to rain at 7.30, and poured down until 3.30 P. M., leaving the lot in a bad and muddy condition for the night's performance, also for the boys to pick up on, as it was another case of carry the stuff to the wagons on the street. Baskir Hadj Ali, one of the Arab boys who was left in Cleveland at the hospital sick, rejoined us to-day. / Business in the afternoon big, but light at night. / Lot, Washington street and Corona avenue."

Note 3: "Nagle"/"Nagles" is S. V. Nagle, an associate of the firm of F. A. Nagle Commission Merchants of Chicago, who attempted to recruit settlers to the lands in the Big Horn Basin that were to be irrigated by the Cody Canal.
Note 4: "Trego" is Charles Trego (1856-1925) who was a personal friend of Cody's and a foreman for both Scout's Rest Ranch in North Platte, Nebraska, and the TE Ranch in Cody, Wyoming.
Note 5: "Foote" is Robert Foote, a democrat and state senator representing Johnson County, Wyoming, from 1895 to 1897. Foote led the effort against the Carey Act in Wyoming.
Note 6: Sage Creek lies east of Cody, Wyoming, flowing north and into the Shoshone River northeast of Cody.
Note 7: The "Town" was officially named Cody, Wyoming, in August 1896.
Note 8: "Cody City," the original name suggested for the new town site of Cody, Wyoming.
